Feeding and eating disorders: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/warning-signs-and-symptoms
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/obsessive-compulsive-disorder/symptoms-causes/syc-20354432
Personality disorders: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/personality-disorders/symptoms-causes/syc-20354463

Dissociative disorders: feeling disconnected from yourself and the world around you
Mood disorders: Major depressive disorder — prolonged and persistent periods of extreme sadness
Trauma and stressor-related disorders: recurrent, involuntary and distressing memories, thoughts, and dreams and flashbacks of the traumatic event
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Feeling that you have to use the drug regularly — daily or even several times a day
Paraphilias: recurrent, intense, sexually arousing fantasies, urges, or behaviors that are distressing or disabling and that involve inanimate objects, children or nonconsenting adults, or suffering or humiliation of oneself or the partner with the potential to cause harm.
Somatic symptom related disorders: Specific sensations, such as pain or shortness of breath, or more general symptoms, such as fatigue or weakness
Sexual dysfunctions: Inability to achieve or maintain an erection (hard penis) suitable for intercourse (erectile dysfunction).
Feeding and eating disorders: In general, behaviors and attitudes that indicate that weight loss, dieting, and control of food are becoming primary concerns
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Angry/irritable mood—often loses temper, easily annoyed, often angry and resentful.
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Fear of contamination or dirt
Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot: Delusions. Having beliefs that do not align with reality.
Personality disorders: Pervasive distrust and suspicion of others and their motives

Anxiety disorders: Having a sense of impending danger, panic or doom
Dissociative disorders: forgetting about certain time periods, events and personal information
Mood disorders: Bipolar disorder — also called manic depression or bipolar affective disorder, depression that includes alternating times of depression and mania
Trauma and stressor-related disorders: avoid internal memories, thoughts, feelings and/or avoid external people, places, situations which are reminders of the traumatic event and become a central focus of the individual’s life.
Sleep-wake disorders: having trouble falling asleep at night
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Having intense urges for the drug that block out any other thoughts
Somatic symptom related disorders: Unrelated to any medical cause that can be identified, or related to a medical condition such as cancer or heart disease, but more significant than what's usually expected
Sexual dysfunctions: Absent or delayed ejaculation despite enough sexual stimulation (retarded ejaculation).
Feeding and eating disorders: Preoccupation with weight, food, calories, carbohydrates, fat grams, and dieting
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Argumentative/defiant behavior—often argues with authority figures or adults, often refuses to comply with requests or rules, deliberately annoys others, blames others for mistakes or misbehavior.
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Doubting and having difficulty tolerating uncertainty
Personality disorders: Unjustified belief that others are trying to harm or deceive you

Dissociative disorders: feeling uncertain about who you are
Mood disorders: Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) — a form of depression most often associated with fewer hours of daylight in the far northern and southern latitudes from late fall to early spring
Trauma and stressor-related disorders: Negative alterations in cognition and mood include problems remembering important aspects of the traumatic event, depression, fear, guilt, shame, and feelings of isolation from others.
Sleep-wake disorders: Some people may fall asleep at inappropriate times, such as while driving
Neuro-cognitive disorders: Changes in a person’s normal behavior
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Over time, needing more of the drug to get the same effect
Somatic symptom related disorders: A single symptom, multiple symptoms or varying symptoms
Sexual dysfunctions: Inability to control the timing of ejaculation (early, or premature, ejaculation).
Feeding and eating disorders: Refusal to eat certain foods, progressing to restrictions against whole categories of food (e.g., no carbohydrates, etc.)
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Needing things orderly and symmetrical
Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot: Hallucinations. Seeing and hearing things or people that aren’t really there.
Personality disorders: Unjustified suspicion of the loyalty or trustworthiness of others

Mood disorders: Cyclothymic disorder — a disorder that causes emotional ups and downs that are less extreme than bipolar disorder
Trauma and stressor-related disorders: Hyper-arousal symptoms include being jumpy and easily startled, irritability, angry outbursts, self-destructive behavior, problems concentrating, and diffculty sleeping.
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Taking larger amounts of the drug over a longer period of time than you intended
Elimination disorders: Scratching or rubbing the anal area due to irritation from watery stools
Feeding and eating disorders: Appears uncomfortable eating around others
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Aggression to people and animals (bullies, intimidates others, initiates fights, use of weapons, cruelty to others, cruelty to animals, stolen while confronting a victim, raped others).
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Aggressive or horrific thoughts about losing control and harming yourself or others
Personality disorders: Hesitancy to confide in others due to unreasonable fear that others will use the information against you

Dissociative disorders: feeling little or no physical pain
Mood disorders: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder — mood changes and irritability that occur during the premenstrual phase of a woman's cycle and go away with the onset of menses
Sleep-wake disorders: feeling an uncomfortable urge to move while you are trying to fall asleep
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Making certain that you maintain a supply of the drug
Somatic symptom related disorders: Viewing normal physical sensations as a sign of severe physical illness
Sexual dysfunctions: Inadequate vaginal lubrication before and during intercourse.
Feeding and eating disorders: Food rituals (e.g. eats only a particular food or food group [e.g. condiments], excessive chewing, doesn’t allow foods to touch)
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Destruction of property (deliberate fire setting, vandalization).
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Unwanted thoughts, including aggression, or sexual or religious subjects
Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot: Disorganized speech or thinking. Jumping from topic to topic with no clear direction.
Personality disorders: Perception of innocent remarks or nonthreatening situations as personal insults or attacks

Mood disorders: Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) — a long-term (chronic) form of depression
Sleep-wake disorders: Unusual or bothersome movements or experiences during sleep are also possible
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Spending money on the drug, even though you can't afford it
Somatic symptom related disorders: Fearing that symptoms are serious, even when there is no evidence
Sexual dysfunctions: Inability to relax the vaginal muscles enough to allow intercourse.
Feeding and eating disorders: Skipping meals or taking small portions of food at regular meals
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Deceitfulness or theft (broken into properties, manipulates others, stolen).
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Fear of being contaminated by touching objects others have touched
Personality disorders: Angry or hostile reaction to perceived slights or insults

Mood disorders: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder — a disorder of chronic, severe and persistent irritability in children that often includes frequent temper outbursts that are inconsistent with the child's developmental age
Sleep-wake disorders: Having an irregular sleep and wake cycle
Neuro-cognitive disorders: Trouble performing daily activities, like driving and managing money
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Not meeting obligations and work responsibilities, or cutting back on social or recreational activities because of drug use
Somatic symptom related disorders: Thinking that physical sensations are threatening or harmful
Sexual dysfunctions: Lack of interest in or desire for sex.
Elimination disorders: Secretive behavior associated with bowel movements
Feeding and eating disorders: Any new practices with food or fad diets, including cutting out entire food groups (no sugar, no carbs, no dairy, vegetarianism/veganism)
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Serious violations of rules (runs away from home, truant from school, stays out at night).
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Doubts that you've locked the door or turned off the stove
Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot: Grossly disorganized or abnormal behavior. Acting peculiar or inappropriate, or being unable to carry out functions of day-to-day living.
Personality disorders: Tendency to hold grudges

Anxiety disorders: Trouble concentrating or thinking about anything other than the present worry
Mood disorders: Depression related to medical illness — a persistent depressed mood and a significant loss of pleasure in most or all activities that's directly related to the physical effects of another medical condition
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Continuing to use the drug, even though you know it's causing problems in your life or causing you physical or psychological harm
Somatic symptom related disorders: Feeling that medical evaluation and treatment have not been adequate
Feeding and eating disorders: Withdrawal from usual friends and activities
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Are out of proportion to the event or incident that triggered them.
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Intense stress when objects aren't orderly or facing a certain way
Personality disorders: Unjustified, recurrent suspicion that spouse or sexual partner is unfaithful

Mood disorders: Depression induced by substance use or medication ― depression symptoms that develop during or soon after substance use or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Doing things to get the drug that you normally wouldn't do, such as stealing
Somatic symptom related disorders: Fearing that physical activity may cause damage to your body
Feeding and eating disorders: Frequent dieting
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Images of driving your car into a crowd of people
Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot: Negative symptoms. Having a diminished or absence of normal behaviors related to motivation and interest (for example, having no motivation to start or complete activities, finding it difficult to feel pleasure, disinterest in social activities) or expression (eg, fewer facial expressions and gestures, difficulty conversing).
Personality disorders: Lack of interest in social or personal relationships, preferring to be alone

Substance-related and addictive disorder: Driving or doing other risky activities when you're under the influence of the drug
Somatic symptom related disorders: Repeatedly checking your body for abnormalities
Feeding and eating disorders: Extreme concern with body size and shape
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Cause much distress for the person.
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Thoughts about shouting obscenities or acting inappropriately in public
Personality disorders: Limited range of emotional expression

Substance-related and addictive disorder: Spending a good deal of time getting the drug, using the drug or recovering from the effects of the drug
Somatic symptom related disorders: Frequent health care visits that don't relieve your concerns or that make them worse
Feeding and eating disorders: Frequent checking in the mirror for perceived flaws in appearance
Disruptive impulse-control, and conduct: Cause problems at work or home.
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Unpleasant sexual images
Personality disorders: Inability to take pleasure in most activities

Anxiety disorders: Having the urge to avoid things that trigger anxiety
Substance-related and addictive disorder: Failing in your attempts to stop using the drug
Somatic symptom related disorders: Being unresponsive to medical treatment or unusually sensitive to medication side effects
Feeding and eating disorders: Extreme mood swings
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Avoidance of situations that can trigger obsessions, such as shaking hands
Personality disorders: Inability to pick up normal social cues

Substance-related and addictive disorder: Experiencing withdrawal symptoms when you attempt to stop taking the drug
Somatic symptom related disorders: Having a more severe impairment than is usually expected from a medical condition
Feeding and eating disorders: Noticeable fluctuations in weight, both up and down
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Washing and cleaning
Personality disorders: Appearance of being cold or indifferent to others

Feeding and eating disorders: Stomach cramps, other non-specific gastrointestinal complaints (constipation, acid reflux, etc.)
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Checking
Personality disorders: Little or no interest in having sex with another person

Feeding and eating disorders: Menstrual irregularities — missing periods or only having a period while on hormonal contraceptives (this is not considered a “true” period)
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Counting
Personality disorders: Peculiar dress, thinking, beliefs, speech or behavior

Feeding and eating disorders: Difficulties concentrating
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Orderliness
Personality disorders: Odd perceptual experiences, such as hearing a voice whisper your name

Feeding and eating disorders: Abnormal laboratory findings (anemia, low thyroid and hormone levels, low potassium, low white and red blood cell counts)
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Following a strict routine
Personality disorders: Flat emotions or inappropriate emotional responses

Feeding and eating disorders: Dizziness, especially upon standing
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Demanding reassurance
Personality disorders: Social anxiety and a lack of or discomfort with close relationships

Feeding and eating disorders: Fainting/syncope
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Hand-washing until your skin becomes raw
Personality disorders: Indifferent, inappropriate or suspicious response to others

Feeding and eating disorders: Feeling cold all the time
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Checking doors repeatedly to make sure they're locked
Personality disorders: Magical thinking — believing you can influence people and events with your thoughts

Feeding and eating disorders: Sleep problems
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Checking the stove repeatedly to make sure it's off
Personality disorders: Belief that certain casual incidents or events have hidden messages meant only for you

Feeding and eating disorders: Cuts and calluses across the top of finger joints (a result of inducing vomiting)
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Counting in certain patterns
Personality disorders: Disregard for others' needs or feelings

Feeding and eating disorders: Dental problems, such as enamel erosion, cavities, and tooth sensitivity
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Silently repeating a prayer, word or phrase
Personality disorders: Persistent lying, stealing, using aliases, conning others

Feeding and eating disorders: Dry skin and hair, and brittle nails
Obsessive-compulsive and related disorde: Arranging your canned goods to face the same way
Personality disorders: Recurring problems with the law

Feeding and eating disorders: Swelling around area of salivary glands
Personality disorders: Repeated violation of the rights of others

Feeding and eating disorders: Fine hair on body (lanugo)
Personality disorders: Aggressive, often violent behavior

Feeding and eating disorders: Cavities, or discoloration of teeth, from vomiting
Personality disorders: Disregard for the safety of self or others

Feeding and eating disorders: Muscle weakness
Personality disorders: Impulsive behavior

Feeding and eating disorders: Yellow skin (in context of eating large amounts of carrots)
Personality disorders: Consistently irresponsible

Feeding and eating disorders: Cold, mottled hands and feet or swelling of feet
Personality disorders: Lack of remorse for behavior

Feeding and eating disorders: Poor wound healing
Personality disorders: Impulsive and risky behavior, such as having unsafe sex, gambling or binge eating

Feeding and eating disorders: Impaired immune functioning
Personality disorders: Unstable or fragile self-image
Unstable and intense relationships
Up and down moods, often as a reaction to interpersonal stress
Suicidal behavior or threats of self-injury
Intense fear of being alone or abandoned
Ongoing feelings of emptiness
Frequent, intense displays of anger
Stress-related paranoia that comes and goes
Constantly seeking attention
Excessively emotional, dramatic or sexually provocative to gain attention
Speaks dramatically with strong opinions, but few facts or details to back them up
Easily influenced by others
Shallow, rapidly changing emotions
Excessive concern with physical appearance
Thinks relationships with others are closer than they really are
Belief that you're special and more important than others
Fantasies about power, success and attractiveness
Failure to recognize others' needs and feelings
Exaggeration of achievements or talents
Expectation of constant praise and admiration
Arrogance
Unreasonable expectations of favors and advantages, often taking advantage of others
